items.title: [question] graph is not a conan command (conan 1.28.1) - fix documenation

labels.name: component: ux
labels.description: No changes to core business logic

items.body:
So since a while when using `conan info -bo` I get the warning that this is deprecated and I should use `conan graph.` So I did with conan 1.25.1 but when upgrading to 1.28.1 (because of another [issue](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/issues/2591)), `conan graph` is gone. The current [documentation for conan info](https://docs.conan.io/en/1.28/reference/commands/consumer/info.html) still says you should use `conan graph` though.

I suggest fixing the documentation and guiding to `conan lock ... ` instead of `conan graph ...`

items.title: [question] how to add build requirements to lockfiles (>=1.28)
[bug] QMake generator does not honour system_libs
items.body:
It seems the QMake generator, [like the SCons generator](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7301), was overlooked in https://github.com/conan-io/conan/pull/5582 which added `cpp_info.system_libs`.

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)

  * Operating System+version: Arch Linux
  * Compiler+version: gcc (GCC) 10.1.0
  * Conan version: 1.28.0
  * Python version: 3.8.5

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)
`conanfile.txt`:

```
[requires]
icu/67.1

[generators]
qmake
```

On Linux, the icu recipe adds `pthread` to `cpp_info.system_libs`:

https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/d6c56bef267cab013b13fbb35b9426735b78bd5e/recipes/icu/all/conanfile.py#L235

However, this is not reflected in the generated conanbuildinfo.pri:

```
$ grep pthread conanbuildinfo.pri
$
$ grep -i _libs conanbuildinfo.pri
CONAN_LIBS += -licui18n -licuio -licutest -licutu -licuuc -licudata
CONAN_LIBS_ICU += -licui18n -licuio -licutest -licutu -licuuc -licudata
    LIBS += $$CONAN_LIBS
        LIBS += $$CONAN_LIBS_RELEASE
        LIBS += $$CONAN_LIBS_DEBUG
```

Indeed `generators/qmake.py`, unlike most of the other generators, does not contain the text `system_libs` anywhere.

My actual problem is not with icu but with a proprietary package that I'm maintaining myself, so as a workaround I tried adding `cpp_info.exeflags.append('-lpthread')`. That gets added to the link command properly, but in the wrong order (it should be after the dependent lib), so it still doesn't work.

A workaround that does work (for me) is to put `self.cpp_info.libs += self.cpp_info.system_libs` at the end of the `package_info` function.

I think the solution for QMake would be to just add system libs to the end of the `*_LIBS` variables.

items.title: [feature] Allow passing options to conan build
items.body:
I'm using `conan build` as a part of build process which doesn't produce conan package as a result. Instead it's used as a convenient wrapper for conan install + cmake + ninja which ensures correct environment variables on all stages. 

It would be very useful if `conan build` allowed passing `-o` arguments like other conan commands like `conan install`. Right now I configure conanfile behavior via environment variables, however using options would be more natural.

items.title: [question] output of deps_cpp_info libdirs differs between 'conan create' and 'conan build'
items.body:
<!-- What is your question? Please be as specific as possible! -->

I am facing a different behaviour, when following conanfile is executed with `conan create . test/testing` and `conan install . && conan build .` using conan version 1.27 and 1.28.
```
from conans import ConanFile

class testApp(ConanFile):
    name = 'test-app'
    version = "0.0.0"
    description = 'test app'
    license = "none"
    url = "none"

    def build_requirements(self):
        self.build_requires("zlib/1.2.11@conan/stable")

    def build(self):
        print("zlib libdirs" + str(self.deps_cpp_info["zlib"].libdirs))
```

1. With conan version <= 1.27 and `conan create . test/testing`  the output of the print is:
```zlib libdirs['lib']```
2. With conan version 1.28 and `conan create . test/testing`  the output of the print is:
```zlib libdirs['lib']```
3. With conan version <= 1.27 and `conan install . && conan build .` the output of the print is:
```zlib libdirs['/home/<user>/.conan/data/zlib/1.2.11/conan/stable/package/1d877a3df840030e6a8abb74c5ffb9088d08b47a/lib']```
4. With conan version 1.28 and `conan install . && conan build .` the output of the print is:
```zlib libdirs['lib']```

Which behaviour is the right one?

- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

items.title: [question] Setup cmake paths for find_path(...) use by consumers
items.body:
Basically I have setup ["build modules"](https://github.com/helmesjo/conan-corrade/blob/9fd823b03d5b97eb437b8844574c5d7e3f06700d/conanfile.py#L123-L127) (cmake scripts) that gets included by consumers (automatically done in the generated `conanbuildinfo.cmake` script). [One of these build modules](https://github.com/mosra/corrade/blob/162d6a7d77e4940f7c05613013e1d3aa522bc8c6/modules/FindCorrade.cmake#L272-L274) uses the cmake function [`find_path(...)`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/find_path.html), but it fails since the packaged structure isn't the same as the original repo. 

What can I do in my recipe to help it find the file? What should I write in `package_info()`?

items.title: [question] Building different conan packages on one machine
items.body:
Hi, 

I have question regarding building and using conan packages on one machine.

I have dedicated machine to run CI stuff on it and I have there downloaded conan packages which work with our master code.
Now, sometimes I have to change conan recipe, rebuild package, check if all tests on master works with this package and then upload this package to conan repository (and then I can use this package with my master CI jobs).

Problem is that during rebuilding packages someone can run CI job which:
- can brake master if package was wrongly rebuilded
- stuck on conan executing because package is rebuilding

I've tried to create virtualenv to manage two different environments, but unfortunately  as far as I see ~/.conan/conan.conf is common for all conan executables. 

**So, is it possible to have two(multiple) different conan storages on one machine and manage those storages parallel?**

I hope you understand my description :)

Br,
Tomasz

items.title: [feature] conan lock build-order should raise when using a lockfile generated with --base as input

labels.name: component: ux
labels.description: No changes to core business logic

items.body:
If you generate a lockfile with `--base`:

`conan lock create conanfile.py --lockfile-out=mylock.lock --build --base`

and right after that you want to use that lockfile to get a build order of the graph

`conan lock build-order mylock.lock`

regardless of the contents of the lockfile you always get `[]` as output.

That's a little bit confusing, I think that an error should be raised saying that you can't use that lockfile to get the build-order of the graph.


- [X] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

items.title: [feature] components to have a 'provides' attribute
items.body:
This is a thought that came up from this really: https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7475

Since [provides](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/attributes.html#provides) now exists, it may make sense to include the provides attribute in the .components as well.

For cases when we have packages, that deliver multiple libs that conflict with one another.

items.title: [feature] component shouldnt require consumers to also use components.
items.body:
I have prepared a repository that you can use to validate the flow without spending your own time on preparing example:
https://github.com/fulara/testing-components/tree/snapshot-github

note this is pretty much a duplicate of: https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7475
However its a question there, and I am requesting the feature here  ( actually I am more leaning towards raising a bug, but its not mentioned anywhere in the docs, so that would be kinda unfair of me . ) 

Short explanation:
liba -> lowest library - wants to expose components.
libb -> library that depends on liba.
bin -> binary that depends on libb
libb-component - equivalent of libb but using dummy component
bin-component - equivalent of bin but depending on libb-component

I would like to have components in liba. 
only a single layer above liba the libb  in my example knows about liba.

So in this case i define `liba`  package_info as follows:
```
    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.components["publisher"].libs = ["publisher"]
        self.cpp_info.components["requester"].libs = ["requester"]
```

and in the libb package_info I am kinda stuck, I dont know how to refer to the components of liba without having to use my component so I am stuck with package_info like this:
```
    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.libs = ["libb"] # because i am using cpp_info.libs conan is causing dependence on whole liba (all libs from it. )
        #self.cpp_info.requires = ["liba::requester"] #i wish this line was working as expected.
```

Now I am going to binary, I am just using cmake_find_package in this case and this is how the cmakelist of th ebin looks like:

```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 2.8)
project(MyHello CXX)

find_package(libb)

add_executable(bin hello.cpp)
target_link_libraries(bin libb::libb)
```

When I build the bin now though this is the linker command i can see:
```
/usr/bin/c++    -rdynamic CMakeFiles/bin.dir/hello.cpp.o  -o bin   .... libpublisher.a ..librequester.a
```
I would like publisher.a  not to be present on that list. 

anyway, I created libb-components and bin-components, it is working as expected ( libpublisher.a  is not appearing on the list ).

I guess it would be somewhat fine if I could do it like this in the libb-component:
```
    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.components[self.name].libs = ["libb"]
        self.cpp_info.components[self.name].requires = ["liba::requester"]
```
but there is an assert against it.


So in short, it looks to me like component forces usage of the component up the stack, and provide unnexpected behavior if someone does not do so, which is counter intuitive.

I think possibly the most natural way of doing this would be adding the .requires on the cpp_info that would allow dependance on individual components, and only allow depending on the components via this.
I saw some assert that told me that i forgot to add .requires to my components when depending on something, so that could be probably added also there.


- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

items.title: [bug] creating iOS packages using simple toolchains broken as of conan 1.26
items.body:
Consider this simple iOS toolchain (based on [this toolchain](https://github.com/microblink/build/blob/master/toolchains/ios.toolchain.cmake)):

```cmake
cmake_minimum_required( VERSION 3.14 )

set( CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID   AppleClang )
set( CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER_ID AppleClang )

if( NOT ${CMAKE_GENERATOR} MATCHES "Xcode" )
    message( FATAL_ERROR "iOS toolchain supports only XCode generator" )
endif()

# Standard settings
set( CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME      iOS    )
set( CMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT      "iphoneos" )
set( CPACK_SYSTEM_NAME      iOS    )
set( CMAKE_SYSTEM_VERSION   8.0    )
set( CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR arm    )
set( CMAKE_OSX_ARCHITECTURES armv7 armv7s arm64 i386 x86_64 )

# Skip the platform compiler checks for cross compiling (or not)...
set( CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER_WORKS true CACHE STRING "Skip CMake compiler detection (requires a functioning code signing identity and provisioning profile)." )
set( CMAKE_C_COMPILER_WORKS   ${CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER_WORKS} )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_EFFECTIVE_PLATFORMS "-universal;-iphonesimulator;-iphoneos;" )
set( CMAKE_IOS_DEVELOPER_ROOT        "/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/iPhoneSimulator.platform/Developer" )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_SDKROOT   iphoneos ) # "Latest iOS"

set( XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7  "-mcpu=cortex-a9 -mfpu=neon" ) 
set( XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7s "-mcpu=swift"                )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_OTHER_CFLAGS[arch=armv7]          "${XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7}  $(OTHER_CFLAGS)"         )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_OTHER_CFLAGS[arch=armv7s]         "${XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7s} $(OTHER_CFLAGS)"         )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_OTHER_CPLUSPLUSFLAGS[arch=armv7]  "${XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7}  $(OTHER_CPLUSPLUSFLAGS)" )
set( CMAKE_XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_OTHER_CPLUSPLUSFLAGS[arch=armv7s] "${XCODE_ATTRIBUTE_CFLAGS_armv7s} $(OTHER_CPLUSPLUSFLAGS)" )
```

Let's create a simple package that contains this toolchain:

```python
import os

from conans import ConanFile


class IostoolchainConan(ConanFile):
    name = "IosToolchain"
    version = "1.2.0"
    # obtain sources, etc.

    def package(self):
        self.copy('ios.toolchain.cmake')

    def package_info(self):
        self.env_info.CONAN_CMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE = os.path.join(self.package_folder, 'ios.toolchain.cmake')
        self.env_info.CONAN_CMAKE_CUSTOM_iOS_ALLOW_UNIVERSAL_BUILD = 'ON'

    def package_id(self):
        self.info.header_only()
```

Also, let's create a conan profile using this toolchain: 

```
[settings]
os=iOS
os.version=8.0
os_build=Macos
arch=ios_fat
arch_build=x86_64
compiler=apple-clang
compiler.libcxx=libc++
build_type=Release
compiler.version=11.0.3

[build_requires]
IosToolchain/1.2.0@microblink/stable

[env]
CONAN_CMAKE_GENERATOR = Xcode
```

Now, let's use this profile to create some package

```
conan create . user/testing -pr ios-profile
```

With Conan 1.25.2 and earlier, everything works. With Conan 1.26.1 and later (also tested with 1.28.0), I get the following CMake configuration error:

```
CMake Error at /Applications/CMake.app/Contents/share/cmake-3.18/Modules/Platform/iOS-Initialize.cmake:4 (message):
  
  /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk
  is not an iOS SDK
...
-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
```

The problem can be traced to how conan's CMake build helper invokes cmake: 

```
cmake -G "Xcode" -DCMAKE_OSX_ARCHITECTURES="None" -DCMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT="/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk" -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE="/Users/dodo/.conan/data/IosToolchain/1.2.0/microblink/stable/package/5ab84d6acfe1f23c4fae0ab88f26e3a396351ac9/ios.toolchain.cmake" -DCONAN_IN_LOCAL_CACHE="ON" -DCONAN_COMPILER="apple-clang" -DCONAN_COMPILER_VERSION="11.0.3" -DCONAN_LIBCXX="libc++" ...
```

The problematic part is `-DCMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT="/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk"` - this overrides the `CMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT` variable as set by the toolchain. Also problematic is `-DCMAKE_OSX_ARCHITECTURES="None"` that does the same.

When executed with `CONAN_PRINT_RUN_COMMANDS=1` by using conan 1.25.2 (or earlier), it can be seen that those two variables are not given via command-line prior to `CMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE`.

I know that from v1.26 there is support for new toolchain mechanism, but I didn't get how should I modify my toolchain files to work with the new conan.

compiler:

```
-- The C compiler identification is TI 18.12.5

elseif(CONAN_COMPILER STREQUAL "ti-cgt-arm")

        conan_error_compiler_version()

items.title: [question] When are conan components expected to become part of official, stable API?
items.body:
I am really keen on using conan as **the** package manager for my team's production code.
However, I am not a big fun of linking all libraries from multi-library dependencies (this can cause problems described https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7475)
Because of that I welcomed introduction of components into conan, but I have been wondering when it is expected for them to become a part of an official API as at the moment they have got an experimental status.

items.title: [feature] Don't Force Cache of Source Folder
items.body:
I feel that we need a configuration option that will always fetch sources during package create, if the user desires the source files to be updated.  Right now I may resort to something like:

`    def configure(self):
        source_dir = os.path.join(os.environ["HOME"], ".conan", "data", self.name, self.version, self.user, self.channel, "source")
        tools.rmdir(source_dir)
`

To ensure that the source() function is invoked, in the event that my conan recipe hasn't changed. items.title: [question] Setting options for your dependencies
items.body:
Hello,

I think my question is similar to #5726, but not exactly same. 

Consider a base package `Base` which exposes an option `fPIC`. 

I am the author of a project called `MyProject` which depends on `Base`. So my conaninfo.txt looks like this:

```
[requires]
Base...

[options]
Base:fPIC = True

[generators]
cmake
```

Everything works correctly so far.
Now, I make a conan package for my project `MyProject` and expose `fPIC` option as well. 

My clients want to use my package now, and their conaninfo.txt looks like this:

```
[requires]
MyPackage...
SomeOther...

[options]
MyPackage:fPIC = True

[generators]
cmake
```

However, this will result in an error since my clients also have to specify `Base:fPIC = True`. The solution suggested in #5726 is to use *, but my client could be depending on a lot of libraries and I don't want them to enable fPIC for all of them. I only want that "if my library is given fPIC, my dependants should be passed that options as well" without clients knowing what all dependencies do I depend on. 

Does my question make sense? (I tried looking at https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/using_packages/conanfile_txt.html#options to see if I can get some info, but couldn't find anything). Let me know if something is not clear.

items.title: [bug] fPIC automatic handling fails when using cmake_find_package generator
items.body:
### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Conan version: 1.27.1

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

When creating a package with `fPIC=True`, the `CMake` build helper will set `CONAN_CMAKE_POSITION_INDEPENDENT_CODE=ON`.

However, this will only work when using the `cmake` generator (and using the `conan_basic_setup` macro, which checks for `CONAN_CMAKE_POSITION_INDEPENDENT_CODE`).
It does nothing when using `cmake_find_package` generators, the `cmake_paths` generator is likely to be affected as well.

The [doc](https://bincrafters.readthedocs.io/en/latest/howtos/add_fpic_option_to_recipe.html) states that the `CMake` helper will set `CMAKE_POSITION_INDEPENDENT_CODE` accordingly though, which is incorrect.

items.title: [feature] Define namespaces for generated entities, such as exported CMake targets
items.body:
It is sometimes desired to change the namespace used for the targets created by the various CMake generators so they can match the targets created by naming schemes outside of Conan (such as the built in find modules or system installed packages). 

One way to tackle this problem would be to use the [filename attribute](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7254) to control the name given to the fine module, and then change the `names` attribute to be whatever the namespace needs to be. 

However to emulate related packages which may share a namespace for targets generated amongst themselves it becomes necessary to share the value for `cppinfo.names` attribute between packages. Because that value is then no longer unique, it's necessary to use the `filename` attribtue to represent a "more unique" value which can be used for generated variables (see the implementation of [this PR](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/pull/7320) where the global variables had to incorporate the filename to work with this [recreate](https://github.com/TimSimpson/conan-pkgs-with-shared-cmake-namespace-recreate) which contains multiple packages that share a namespace). 

It could simplify things to introduce a seperate attribute explicitly tied to the concept of a namespace in generated entities. This could then be used by the cmake generators.

As an example of how this attribute might be used, consider two packages from a theoretical modularized Boost:

```python
def package_info(self):
    self.cpp_info.namespaces["cmake_find_package"] = "boost"
    self.cpp_info.components["coroutine"].names = "coroutine"
```

```python
def package_info(self):
    self.cpp_info.namespaces["cmake_find_package"] = "boost"
    self.cpp_info.components["asio"].names = "asio"
```

items.title: [bug] conan install only considers exports_sources
items.body:
### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Conan version: 1.26.0+

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

Put a `dummy.txt` next to the following `conanfile.py` in some directory.

    # conanfile.py
    from conans import ConanFile
    from os.path import isfile


    class ExportSourcesTestConan(ConanFile):
        name = "export-sources-test"
        version = "1.0"
        settings = None
        #exports_sources = "dummy.txt",

        def export_sources(self):
            self.copy("dummy.txt")

        def build(self):
            if not isfile("dummy.txt"):
                raise RuntimeError("Oh no!")

Create and upload the package

    $ conan create . user/testing
    $ conan upload -r <remote> export-sources-test/1.0@user/testing

Remove the package from the local cache and install it from your remote:

    $ conan remove export-sources-test*
    $ conan install export-sources-test/1.0@user/testing --build missing

If the `conanfile.py` uses `export_sources()` the build step will raise the exception. If `exports_sources` is used, the build step succeeds.

### Cause

The function `complete_recipe_sources()` in `client/source.py` only tests whether `conanfile.exports_sources` is defined. If only `export_sources()` is defined the sources won't be downloaded and the source directory stays empty.

### Workaround

Defining both `exports_sources` and `export_sources()` triggers the download of the sources. But it would be nice to use `export_sources()` completely independent from `exports_sources`.

        def package_info(self):

In the MyExe I have the following imports and package:

My issue is, that during `conan create` of MyExe, the MyLib-shared object is imported, but it is not put into the package folder. Furthermore it is gone from the build folder too (after the build of MyExe is finished). The excerpt of the console output during a conan create is:

and near the end:

My understanding is that during the package-step of the MyExe, not only the executable, but also the shared object should be packaged. But this is not the case and I'm wondering why.

items.title: [feature] CMake generators: include 'build_modules' after creating the packages
items.body:
Duplicated:  https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7261

---

This is a last-mile problem for CMake. Some packages provide CMake modules with some customization that doesn't fit the general conventions and we cannot keep adding more complexity to the `cpp_info` model:
 * `OpenSSL` has a different casing for the filename and the variables provided by it: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.6/module/FindOpenSSL.html
 * `cereal` provides a `cereal-config.cmake` that offers targets without namespace (https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/issues/2151), `SPIRV-tools` too (IIRC).
 * ...there are many details hidden in other packages

If we really want to provide transparent integration, this last-mile details cannot be supported in the `cpp_info`, but they can be added to the `build_modules`, those files are included for all the CMake generates and they can populate other variables based on the value of existing ones and they could create custom targets (or alias)...


To be able to implement this feature, some work/research to be done:
 * include `build_modules` after creating the targets for `cmake_find_package[_multi]` generators.
 * `build_modules` need to know the generator used, so they know if targets are available or not (depending on the generator, or **even depending on the `TARGET` argument to `conan_basic_setup`**).

items.title: [feature] Stop forcing User-Agent, or change it to not include "requests"
items.body:
While making a recipe for one of the libraries, I ran into interesting issue where Conan's downloader (`tools.get` used to download the zipped package of source code) would fail to download the file with status 406 - wget or any other client would download it without a problem. I digged a bit and figured out that "User-Agent" is the culprit - the server seems to not like the "requests" string, which is understandable as many scrapers / scripts will use this if someone doesn't bother to change it. Unfortunately Conan implements it in a way that prevents easy overriding it - it always forces "User-Agent" header to be `Conan/x.x.x (Python x.x.x) python-requests/x.x.x`.

There are a couple workarounds, I just went for passing immutable dictionary as headers to `get` method, which prevented Conan from modifying my "User-Agent" header, but I think it would be good if Conan would use just "Conan/ver" as a User-Agent, and drop the requests legacy, as it can cause problems like the one I have, and it's really not something you want to fight against. I think Conan is widely known now and using it as a user agent would be justified, and enforcing information about Python version or that it uses requests library does nothing really, except for giving headaches like the one I had.

items.title: [bug] Misleading/wrong "--update" handling for conan graph lock
items.body:
Hi all,

It seems to me that the "conan graph lock" handles the "--update" parameter incorrectly; or, alternatively, that the documentation is misleading.

When running a "conan graph lock" with the "--update" parameters, the packages are not updated from the remote. If the local cache has an outdated version, and a remote has a later version (at least a later package revision, I'm not sure if this is true if the versions differ), then the resulting lockfile will still use the cached, older version. This does not match what I would expect from the documentation.

This is caused by conan_api.py, create_lock. Here, the "update" parameter is passed to load_graph's check_updates parameter, while load_graph's update parameter is always set to False. This results in ConanProxy's _get_recipe to trigger the code path with status RECIPE_UPDATEABLE, instead of RECIPE_UPDATED. Finally, this causes the lockfile to contain the older package revisions.

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Windows 10
  * Compiler+version: N/A
  * Conan version: 1.25.2/1.27.0
  * Python version: 3.8.3

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)
 - Enable package revisions
 - Make a package A/1.0.0 depend on B/1.0.0, where B/1.0.0 is uploaded to a remote (artifactory)
 - Have a locally cached version of B/1.0.0
 - Change B/1.0.0 (keeping the version) and upload it to the remote (artifactory), without changing the local cache (e.g. on another system)
 - Run "conan graph lock A/1.0.0@\_/\_ --update --build missing --build outdated --build cascade --lockfile ."
 - Open the lockfile and see the version of B/1.0.0 being used; this is the version of the local cache, rather than the update from the remote

Best regards,
SpoofedEx

        self.cpp_info.components["crypto"].names['pkg_config'] = 'libcrypto'
        self.cpp_info.components["ssl"].names["cmake_find_package"] = "SSL"
        self.cpp_info.components["ssl"].names["cmake_find_package_multi"] = "SSL"
        self.cpp_info.components["ssl"].names['pkg_config'] = 'libssl'
```

How do components work with `pkg_config`?

items.title: [bug] Regression in linker flags list definition with macOS/iOS framework linker flags
items.body:
### Environment Details
  * Conan version: >= 1.25.0

### Steps to reproduce
**conanfile.py**
```
from conans import ConanFile

class Package1Conan(ConanFile):
    name = "package-1"
    version = "9.9.9"
    settings = "os", "arch", "compiler", "build_type"
    options = {"shared": [True, False]}
    default_options = {"shared": False}

    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.exelinkflags.extend(['-framework Foundation'])
```
**test_package/conanfile.py**
```
from conans import ConanFile, CMake

class TestPackage1Conan(ConanFile):
    settings = "os", "arch", "compiler", "build_type"
    generators = "cmake_find_package"

    def build(self):
        cmake = CMake(self)
        cmake.configure()
        cmake.build()
```
**test_package/CMakeLists.txt**
```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.0)
project(test_package)

find_package(package-1)

add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} test_package.cpp)
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} package-1::package-1)
```

### Logs
```
[100%] Linking CXX executable test_package
ld: framework not found -lFoundation
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
```

Caused by the generator expression definition of the linker flag list, which seems to be caused by the fix for #6779 
```
set(package-1_LINKER_FLAGS_LIST
        $<$<STREQUAL:$<TARGET_PROPERTY:TYPE>,SHARED_LIBRARY>:>
        $<$<STREQUAL:$<TARGET_PROPERTY:TYPE>,EXECUTABLE>:-framework Foundation>
)
```

items.title: [feature] Conan should recognize elementaryOS as a distro that uses apt
items.body:
elementaryOS is a Linux distro based on Ubuntu. So, it uses `apt`. However, Conan, via the `conans` module, disagrees and says that it does not use `apt` when calling `tools.os_info.with_apt`.

```
Python 3.7.4 (default, Oct  9 2019, 00:16:19) 
[GCC 7.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from conans import tools
>>> tools.os_info.with_apt
False
```

Letting Conan know that elementaryOS uses `apt` is important since recipes that have to know whether or not the distro they are running in uses `apt` may have to resort to doing something less than ideal when ran under elementaryOS. For example, using `opengl/system` in a project under elementaryOS will fail (just like [this](https://github.com/bincrafters/community/issues/1216#issuecomment-653540067) in bincrafters/community#1216) because the recipe, as [it is currently is](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/97d32ad939ce0acebe681201ef95896736ce1946/recipes/opengl/all/conanfile.py#L60) (and supported by conan-io/conan-center-index#2114), fails hard when being used in an unrecognized distro.

As such, Conan should be updated to recognize elementaryOS as a distro that uses `apt`. Based on my quick skim of the `conans` module code, it seems that a change in [`client/tools/oss.py:181`](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/d40f2a9f644c390bfaf202a573d7fb999a30949f/conans/client/tools/oss.py#L181) to:

```
# ...
        apt_distros = ("debian", "ubuntu", "knoppix", "linuxmint", "raspbian", "neon", "pop", "elementary")
# ...
````

should do the trick.

Note: `import distro; distro.id()` returns `'elementary'`.

- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

items.title: [bug] The SCons generator doesn't export system_libs
items.body:
<!--
  Please don't forget to update the issue title.
  Include all applicable information to help us reproduce your problem.

  To help us debug your issue please explain:
-->

As a bit of background, I recently had a very strange issue with icu/67.1. Specifically, when I built the release build, it produced linking errors. The debug build was strangely fine, but this turned out to be random.

A few rabbit holes and a few hours later, I managed to figure out why -- I wasn't linking against `-ldl` and `-lpthread`. Linking against only `-ldl` didn't cause link errors, but it caused `System error: -1` (or something along the lines of that) at runtime.

I decided to run the linker into verbose mode, and noticed several libraries were missing. I cross-referenced with the recipe, and in the  debug build, the flags weren't present. I checked the  SConscript file generated several times, but the last time around I noticed that there was no -pthread or -ldl. I also just confirmed these two were only included because of my use of sanitizers - it working this far has been pure luck.

Finally, the problem itself, and the reason I'm opening this issue here, is that the SCons generator [doesn't export system_libs](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/conans/client/generators/scons.py#L15). That's why it fails to link or run.

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Linux Mint 19.3
  * Compiler+version: Clang 10
  * Conan version: 1.27.0
  * Python version: 3.8.0

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

conanfile.py:
```python
from conans import ConanFile

class Taskranger(ConanFile):
    settings = "os", "compiler", "build_type", "arch"
    generators = "ycm", "scons"

    default_options = {
        "icu:data_packaging": "static",
        "icu:shared": False
    }

    def requirements(self):
        self.requires("icu/67.1")
```

main.cpp:
```cpp
#include "unicode/smpdtfmt.h"

int main() {
    using namespace icu;
    UErrorCode status = U_ZERO_ERROR;
    SimpleDateFormat sdf(UnicodeString("dd.MM.y"), status);
}
```
SConstruct:
```python
env = Environment(CXXFLAGS="-std=c++17")
flags = SConscript("build/SConscript_conan")
env.MergeFlags(flags["conan"])
print(flags)
env.Program("demo", "main.cpp")
```
Commands after placing the files above in a directory:
```
mkdir build
cd build
conan install .. --build missing
scons ..
```
... and watch the compiler come up with undefined references to `-ldl` stuff. With `with_dyload: False`, it will compile, but it throws an `std::system_error` because pthreads isn't linked. [Both of these are defined as `system_libs`](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/master/recipes/icu/all/conanfile.py#L233-L235), neither are included in the flags generated by the SCons generator. This should in theory, in a simple enough environment, happen to any and all packages using system_libs.

Output with:

Default settings:
```
g++ -o main.o -c -std=c++17 -DU_STATIC_IMPLEMENTATION -I/home/lunarwatcher/.conan/data/icu/67.1/_/_/package/b840526c6db636afcf60cda7b7728f7e08d6bb6e/include main.cpp
g++ -o demo main.o -L/home/lunarwatcher/.conan/data/icu/67.1/_/_/package/b840526c6db636afcf60cda7b7728f7e08d6bb6e/lib -licui18n -licuio -licutest -licutu -licuuc -licudata
/home/lunarwatcher/.conan/data/icu/67.1/_/_/package/b840526c6db636afcf60cda7b7728f7e08d6bb6e/lib/libicuuc.a(putil.ao): In function `uprv_dl_open_67':
putil.cpp:(.text.uprv_dl_open_67+0x13): undefined reference to `dlopen'
/home/lunarwatcher/.conan/data/icu/67.1/_/_/package/b840526c6db636afcf60cda7b7728f7e08d6bb6e/lib/libicuuc.a(putil.ao): In function `uprv_dl_close_67':
putil.cpp:(.text.uprv_dl_close_67+0x7): undefined reference to `dlclose'
/home/lunarwatcher/.conan/data/icu/67.1/_/_/package/b840526c6db636afcf60cda7b7728f7e08d6bb6e/lib/libicuuc.a(putil.ao): In function `uprv_dlsym_func_67':
putil.cpp:(.text.uprv_dlsym_func_67+0xe): undefined reference to `dlsym'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
scons: *** [demo] Error 1
scons: building terminated because of errors.
```

`with_dyload: False`:
```
❯ ./demo
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::system_error'
  what():  Unknown error -1
[1]    6878 abort (core dumped)  ./demo
```

items.title: [bug] Infinite recursion when checking for an option in the package_id method
items.body:
Thank you for all the great work in conan!  I was working on a base class that would invoke `shared_library_package_id` conditionally if "shared" was in the options.  (A try-catch would work for this case, but I was working through some ideas.)  I found that the `in` lookup was causing infinite stack recursion.

```python
def package_id(self):
    if "not_an_option" in self.info.options:
        self.info.shared_library_package_id()
```

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Ubuntu 16.04.5
  * Conan version: Conan version 1.27.0
  * Python version: Python 3.5.2

Also tested in the docker:

  * Conan versions: 1.0.0, 1.10.0, 1.27.0
  * Docker container:  `conanio/gcc5`

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

1. Create a new conanfile:
   ```bash
   conan new test/1.0@user/testing
   ```
1. Append a `package_id` method which looks for an option that doesn't exist:
   ```bash
   printf "    def package_id(self):\n        'not_an_option' in self.info.options" >> conanfile.py
   ```
1. Attempt to create a package:

   ```

**Expected:** Builds 
**Actual:** 100% CPU and eventually 100% RAM

items.title: [bug] Automated config update exception needed for conan config install commands to prevent catch-22
items.body:
Relates to the feature discussed in https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7282

I think I just ran into a bug with this.

I had made a personal fork of our teams config to test out making this change, and used it to set up my own client with:

```
conan config install git@bbgithub.dev.mycorp.com:mmaguir1/conan_common_config_install.git --type git
```

I tested that, it worked fine, I got approval and landed the PR on our team's repo, and deleted my fork.

Today I went to perform a conan operation, which failed because the fork no longer exists.

So I thought, "no problem" I'll just re-set up my config to be from my team's repo:

```
C:\dev\src\PORT\pract>conan config install git@bbgithub.dev.mycorp.com:team/conan_common_config_install.git --type git
Trying to clone repo: git@bbgithub.dev.mycorp.com:mmaguir1/conan_common_config_install.git
ERROR: Can't clone repo: Command 'git -c http.sslVerify=true clone "git@bbgithub.dev.mycorp.com:mmaguir1/conan_common_config_install.git" .   ' returned non-zero exit status 128.
Cloning into '.'...
ERROR: Repository not found.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
```

It now won't let me fix the problem, because before the new config install location can be set, it tries to check the old, non-existent location and errors out.  

Of course I worked around this, but can we please add an exception to the automated scheduler checks for `conan config install` commands themselves?

items.title: [bug] same build requirement added twice to the lockfile
items.body:
Build requirements are duplicated in lockfiles, if multiple packages in the graph depend on them. Furthermore, the build profile is not applied when installing a packages referencing a lockfile.

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS
  * Compiler+version: gcc-linaro
  * Conan version: 1.26.1
  * Python version: 3.7

### Steps to reproduce
#### Initial situation
- We have pkgA, pkgB, which are simple CMake libraries
- pkgA requires pkgB
- There is a gcc-linaro package containing a cross compiler for ARMv8. As the compiler only runs on Linux, the settings are restricted to `os=Linux, arch=x86_64`
- There is a build_profile which sets `os=Linux, arch = x86_64`
- There is a host_profile with:
```
[settings]
os=Linux
arch=armv8
compiler=gcc
compiler.version=7.5
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11
build_type=Release

[build_requires]
gcc-linaro/7.3-2018.05@user/channel
```

Then, I did the following steps:
1. export all recipes to conan cache (`conan export ... user/channel`)
2. install dependencies of recipeA (`conan install recipeA/conanfile.py user/channel --build=missing -pr:h profile_host -pr:b profile_build`)
3. create packageA (`conan install recipeA/0.1@user/channel --lockfile`

#### Outcome
step 2 creates a lockfile, in which there is (simplified):
```
0 -> pkgA
    requires: 1
    build-requires: 3
1 -> pkgB
   build_requires: 2
2 -> gcc-linaro/0.1@user/channel#rrev:pkgID#prev
3 -> gcc-linaro/0.1@user/channel#rrev:pkgID
```
Why does gcc-linaro appear twice in the lockfile? Shouldn't conan detect that they are the same (the rrev and pkgID are the same)?

Step 3 fails with the error:
```
ERROR: Error while initializing settings. Invalid setting 'armv8' is not a valid 'settings.arch' value.
Possible values are ['x86_64']
```
Conan tries to build gcc-linaro again (due to the duplicate entry in the lockfile), and doesn't apply the build profile any more.

Is is possible to perform Autotools configure below using default profile instead of Emscripten profile?

```
def build(self):

```

items.title: [question] ERROR: Build-require 'b2' cannot be found in lockfile
items.body:
I am currently transitioning our build scripts from _conan info --build-order_ to the recommended _conan graph build-order_ and experience issues with build_requires. I have a couple of libraries and some of them depend on boost. And boost has a [build_require set to b2](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/master/recipes/boost/all/conanfile.py#L143).

In my minimal [conan-recipe](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/files/4850404/conanfile.txt) I require boost with certain settings (the same as in the real consumer conan recipe).

I create a lockfile via (supplying all profiles, see attached [bo.txt](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/files/4850406/bo.txt))
`conan graph lock -s arch=x86 bo.lock version/Base/conanfile.py`

which works fine, but when I try to get the build-order via
`conan graph build-order bo.lock --build --json=bo.json`
it fails with the error-message: 
**ERROR: Build-require 'b2' cannot be found in lockfile**

Using `conan info --build-order ALL -s arch=x86 version/Base/conanfile.py` complains that is deprecated, but deliveres the expected result.
```
conan info --build-order ALL -s arch=x86 version/Base/conanfile.py
WARN: Usage of '--build-order' argument is deprecated and can return wrong results. Use 'conan graph build-order ...' instead.`
[b2/4.2.0], [boost/1.73.0]
```
**Conan-Version** I use is **1.25.1** and I am working within the Debian WSL.

Is this a known limitation or am I missing something?

items.title: [bug][triaging] shared_library_package_id() makes conan create call fail with empty error message
items.body:
<!--
  Please don't forget to update the issue title.
  Include all applicable information to help us reproduce your problem.

  To help us debug your issue please explain:
-->

### Environment Details
  * Operating System+version: macOS Catalina 10.15.4
  * Compiler+version: apple-clang 10.0
  * Conan version: 1.26.0 (error not exclusive to this version)
  * Python version: 3.7.7

### Steps to reproduce
The minimal code which displays the problem, along with more details and reproduction steps is uploaded [here](https://github.com/jbatnozic/conan-create-error-demo-2).

Basically, the issue is that if you have a chain of dependencies which are by default static, except the top-level one which you want to build as shared, you have to call shared_library_package_id() in its package_id method so that all package IDs are generated properly. However, if any of the upstream dependencies are not available in cache and need to be built locally, package creation fails with an empty error message.

items.title: [feature] Allow setting description and URL dynamically
items.body:
Issue #5881 made it possible to set the package name and version after they are read from for example an external file.

In our company we use this to prevent that we have to specify the project name and version in both the CMakeLists.txt and the conanfile.py. I created a ConanFile derived class that reads this information from the 'project()' cmake command (see https://github.com/wdobbe/conan-extra/tree/master/cmake_conan).

The cmake project() command also allows to specify the description and URL. They are then used as default for for example the (RPM) package metadata fields.
Although not super important, it would be nice if the ConanFile class also had set_description() and set_url() functions, analog to the set_name() and set_version() functions. This would prevent that we have to specify the description and URL in both the cmake and conan files.

- [x ] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

items.title: [feature] Define file name for CMake find generators
items.body:
Coming from https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/7217#issuecomment-648998898

closes #6069

There is one limitation regarding the name of the find_package files and targets in CMake. Currently, the name specified in `self.cpp_info.names["cmake_find_package"]` is the one used to generate the *Find<name>.cmake* as well as the namespace for the targets `<name>::component`.

There are use cases where those names are different, for example protobuf has *FindProtobuf.cmake* while the targets are `protobuf::libprotobuf`.

The proposal for this would be to add something like `self.cpp_info.filename["cmake_find_package"] = "Protobuf"` so both names can be defined in the recipe:

```
    def pacakge_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.filename["cmake_find_package"] = "Protobuf"
        self.cpp_info.names["cmake_find_package"] = "protobuf"
        self.cpp_info.components["libprotobuf"] = "libprotobuf"
```

cc/ @TimSimpson @uilianries

items.title: [feature] Declare what a recipe 'provides'
items.body:
Add a `provides` attribute to the ConanFile class, it will list other package names that define the same functionality. Some examples:
 * `libjpeg`, `libjpeg-turbo`, `mozjpeg` are different implementations of the same functionality and break the ODR principle. 
 * deprecated recipes like `cpp-taskflow` that takes the new name `taskflow`
 * frameworks and individual libraries like a monolith `boost` and a modular one

All of them will introduce duplicated functionality in the graph (probably linking problems) that we want to avoid.

Recipes `mozjpeg` and `libjpeg-turbo` will contain a `provides = "libjpeg"` attribute and Conan will raise if both are present in the graph (any alternative and the _master_ one).

The workaround for this situation is to replace the requirement modifying one recipe in the middle to change the requirements, but eventually it will remove all the alternative implementations from the graph. **The actual solution would be to create a "proxy/virtual" recipe that, based on an option, will choose one of the implementations**, and all the recipes should require that proxy recipe instead of the actual jpeg implementation. Conan built-in functionality ensures that there is only one instance of the proxy recipe and there will be only one implementation of the actual functionality.

We should provide a POC together with the feature implementation to check it actually works.

items.title: [feature] Add 'deprecated' attribute to ConanFile

labels.name: component: ux
labels.description: No changes to core business logic

items.body:
Add a `deprecated` attribute to ConanFile class:
 * _falsy_ value will do nothing
 * _truthy_ value will print a standardized warning to the user (probably during the configuration step): the value can contain the name/reference of another recipe that supersedes this one.

```python
class Recipe(ConanFile):
    name = "cpp-taskflow"

    deprecated = "taskflow"
```

```bash
$ conan install cpp-taskflow/1.0
...
WARN.- Recipe 'cpp-taskflow/1.0' is deprecated in favor of 'taskflow/1.0'. Please, consider changing your requirements.
...
